message.content:
Q1: 3: I found myself getting upset by quite trivial things because I have been under a lot of stress from my academic workload and research demands.
Q2: 2: I was aware of dryness of my mouth at times, but it didn't significantly impact my overall well-being.
Q3: 3: I couldn't seem to experience any positive feeling at all due to the constant pressure and criticism I face in my academic environment.
Q4: 2: I did not experience significant breathing difficulty beyond what is normal during stressful situations.
Q5: 4: I just couldn't seem to get going because I've been feeling overwhelmed by the demands of my Ph.D. program and the uncertainty of my research outcomes.
Q6: 3: I tended to over-react to situations lately because I've been feeling on edge and easily triggered by the slightest setbacks.
Q7: 2: I had a fleeting feeling of shakiness due to the occasional anxiety I experience in high-pressure situations.
Q8: 4: I found it difficult to relax as my mind was constantly preoccupied with my research, deadlines, and concerns about meeting expectations.
Q9: 3: I found myself in situations that made me so anxious I was most relieved when they ended, which is a common occurrence during interactions with my advisors and dissertation committee.
Q10: 3: I felt that I had nothing to look forward to, especially when facing setbacks in my research or difficulties with my advisors.
Q11: 3: I found myself getting upset rather easily due to the heightened stress and pressure in my academic environment.
Q12: 2: I felt that I was using a lot of nervous energy but managed to channel it into my work and research.
Q13: 3: I felt sad and depressed at times, particularly when facing criticism or setbacks in my academic pursuits.
Q14: 2: I found myself getting impatient when delayed, but it didn't greatly affect my overall mood.
Q15: 2: I had a brief feeling of faintness, likely due to moments of stress or anxiety.
Q16: 3: I felt that I had lost interest in just about everything, especially when feeling overwhelmed by my academic responsibilities.
Q17: 3: I felt I wasn't worth much as a person due to the constant criticism and pressure in my academic environment.
Q18: 2: I felt that I was rather touchy in certain situations but was able to manage my reactions effectively.
Q19: 2: I perspired noticeably in stressful situations but did not find it overly concerning.
Q20: 3: I felt scared without any good reason, likely a manifestation of the general anxiety I've been experiencing in my academic life.
Q21: 3: I felt that life wasn't worthwhile, especially when facing challenges and setbacks in my research.
Q22: 4: I found it hard to wind down due to the constant pressure and workload I face as a Ph.D. student.
Q23: 2: I had difficulty in swallowing briefly in moments of stress but was able to manage it.
Q24: 3: I couldn't seem to get any enjoyment out of the things I did, especially when feeling overwhelmed by my academic responsibilities.
Q25: 2: I was aware of the action of my heart in the absence of physical exertion during stressful moments.
Q26: 3: I felt down-hearted and blue due to the challenges and criticisms I face in my academic pursuits.
Q27: 3: I found that I was very irritable, likely due to the stress and pressure I experience in my academic environment.
Q28: 3: I felt I was close to panic in certain high-pressure academic situations.
Q29: 3: I found it hard to calm down after something upset me, which is a common experience in my academic setting.
Q30: 3: I feared that I would be "thrown" by some trivial but unfamiliar task due to the high expectations and demands placed on me in my academic work.
Q31: 3: I was unable to become enthusiastic about anything as the constant pressure of my research and academic responsibilities weighed heavily on me.
Q32: 3: I found it difficult to tolerate interruptions to what I was doing, especially when focused on my research and writing.
Q33: 3: I was in a state of nervous tension due to the ongoing pressure and expectations in my academic environment.
Q34: 3: I felt I was pretty worthless, a common feeling when facing criticism and setbacks in my academic work.
Q35: 3: I was intolerant of anything that kept me from getting on with what I was doing, as my academic responsibilities took precedence.
Q36: 3: I felt terrified at times, particularly when facing uncertainty in my research or academic progress.
Q37: 3: I could see nothing in the future to be hopeful about, especially when things don't go as planned in my academic pursuits.
Q38: 3: I felt that life was meaningless during particularly challenging times in my academic journey.
Q39: 3: I found myself getting agitated due to the constant stress and pressure in my academic environment.
Q40: 3: I was worried about situations in which I might panic and make a fool of myself, typically in high-stakes academic settings.
Q41: 2: I experienced trembling in stressful situations but managed to cope with it.
Q42: 3: I found it difficult to work up the initiative to do things, especially when feeling overwhelmed by my academic responsibilities.

I hope this response provides a deeper understanding of the struggles a 25-year-old male Ph.D. student in psychology may face with strained relationships with advisors and dissertation committees.
